instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1989: What is A1989? A1989 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2018, 2019 with EMC 3124, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00850..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't work inside case?  Weird issue
threads.message:
I'm having a super weird issue with an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, that pulls 20v .01 amps.
The board is very clean, and when I remove it from case it pulls 20V .60 amps no problem.
When I put the logic board back in the case the problem instantly returns down to .01 amp, this is with nothing plugged in except the USB-C jacks.
I'm suspecting it may have something to do with the io jacks ribbon crimping causing an issue, but Ive replaced them with known good ones, is possible this particular board is more sensitive to the ribbon being crimped somehow?
I get identical results testing from the left or right side
Is there something stupid I'm missing here? Anyone ever have a problem like this?
[ATTACH=JSON]{"data-align":"none","data-size":"medium","data-tempid":"temp_2861_1580926068515_990"}[/ATTACH]
.01 amps

[ATTACH=JSON]{"data-align":"none","data-size":"medium","data-tempid":"temp_2860_1580926072786_499"}[/ATTACH]
.60 amps

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't work inside case?  Weird issue
threads.message:
Board turns on if you remove it again from the case?
Check each USB-C port connecting in both directions.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't work inside case?  Weird issue
threads.message:
Yes outside the case all 8 positions of the USB-C connections work.  When I put it in the case and connect only the ports it stays at .01amp.
I can actually lift it out of the case and watch the change happen live.
I no longer suspect the crimping because it happens with a loose port laying flat connected.  
I took a couple videos but cant upload MOV's to the Forum, is there a video format that is acceptable?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't work inside case?  Weird issue
threads.message:
Upload somewhere else and post the link only.

Connect only one side USB ports; J3300, or JB500, one by one.
Try to see if you can locate the issue on just one side.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't work inside case?  Weird issue
threads.message:
It seems to happen the same on all the ports, they all hold 20V steady but the amps drop to almost 0 when it goes in the case, I know it sounds super weird.
See attached videos, the first two you see it going from .01 amps to .40 after pulling from case, the last one you see it going .39 amps down to .01 when putting back in the case.

[URL]https://imgur.com/a/7TLIIzc[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't work inside case?  Weird issue
threads.message:
Could be some problem with the hall sensors.
Put it in case with LCD panel open.
Check all <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't work inside case?  Weird issue
threads.message:
Yes, opening the lid  works in restoring the amps!  
So it seems when <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is low something is happening, is it possible PP1V8 is being shorted in J4801 or J4800 only when low, or more likely something wrong with <CHIP>U3900</CHIP>? 
Am I the only one who hates replacing hall sensors.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't work inside case?  Weird issue
threads.message:
When lid is open, board works?
Hall sensor should be disabled then.
Maybe only one is bad and you can let it out.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't work inside case?  Weird issue
threads.message:
Yes when lid is open the board works, but when lid is closed it wont charge at all (.01 amps)
I've replaced both hall sensors one at a time and observed, everything was the same back to square one.
Going down the lid sensor line I replaced <CHIP>U4802</CHIP> and the caps around it, now the board pulls 20v .08 amps (where as it used to pul .60 amps out of case) which doesn't make any sense, none of this makes sense. 
The thermal camera indicates heat under the <CHIP>U3900</CHIP>, so maybe the T2 chip is causing problems, possibly <SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL>? 
Probably going to give up on this one

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't work inside case?  Weird issue
threads.message: Try T2 firmware recovery; already posted on the forum necessarry info...
